description.narrative: The project seeks to transform the rapidly growing rural housing sector in Uzbekistan towards a more sustainable and low-carbon development pathway by designing, piloting and scaling-up a green mortgage market mechanism.

activity-description.narrative: Piloting 112 green mortgages for construction of low-carbon affordable rural houses in Surxondaryo province
Piloting 121 green mortgages for construction of low-carbon affordable rural houses in Fergana province
Piloting 176 green mortgages for construction of low-carbon affordable rural houses in Samarkand region
Piloting 185 green mortgages for construction of low-carbon affordable rural houses in Xorazm province
Piloting 206 green mortgages for construction of low-carbon affordable rural houses in Buxoro province

sector.narrative: Eradicate poverty in all its forms and dimensions

description.narrative: Indicator 1 1.1 Total Lifetime Direct and Indirect GHG Emissions Avoided (tCO2eq) 1.2 Lifetime energy saved (expressed in GJ) 1.3 Volume of investment mobilized and leveraged by GEF for low GHG development (co-financing and additional financing) 1.4 # of users of low-GHG systems (# of female) 1.5 # of new development partnerships with funding for improved energy efficiency and/or sustainable energy solutions targeting underserved communities/groups and women 1.6 Satisfaction (measured on a five-point scale) of beneficiaries and other local benefits generated 1.7 Status (Yes/No) of non-grant mechanisms and/or incentives to invest in houses and other infrastructure featuring low-carbon design and/or technologies 1.8 # of households (#of people, including # of women) accessed financial products for carbon housing offered by financial institutions 1.9 # of rural households with access to houses with EE/RE technologies 1.10 # of energy audits to measure energy performance of the EE and low-carbon houses and reflect significant improvements over standard RHP houses 1.11 # focus group (gender disaggregated) convened during the rural TNA stakeholder consultations 1.12 # of companies and volume of their sales through supply chain for low-carbon rural housing 1.13 # of building codes introduced for housing in Uzbekistan with requirements for energy performance that are at least 30% stricter than existing codes 1.14 Rate of compliance with applicable energy performance standards in residential building codes 1.15 # of specialists (architects, builders, designers, etc.) certified/successfully completing training in the new codes, design review, certification, and compliance issues and techniques 1.16 # of land-use plans and/or zoning regulations improved to maximize efficient resource use and incorporate climate considerations 1.17 # of communities (or districts) supported incorporating climate change considerations into decision-making 1.18 % of project stakeholders and % of

comment.narrative: Baseline 1: 1.1 No significant GHG emissions avoided – current construction techniques and building codes will “lock in” a higher-than-necessary trajectory of emissions in the housing sector 1.2 In the absence of the project, fossil fuel consumption will continue to grow in the rural housing sector due to increases in the size of the housing stock in spite of selected energy efficiency gains 1.3 Investments in energy efficiency are not currently made in the rural housing sector 1.4 Low-GHG systems are not currently used to any significant extent in rural areas of Uzbekistan 1.5 There is no any development partnerships with funding for improved energy efficiency and/or sustainable energy solutions targeting underserved communities/groups and women 1.6 Satisfaction and benefits accruing to residents are not currently measured 1.7 There is currently no mechanism to leverage existing investments in rural housing to cover EE and RE technologies in rural houses 1.8 Banks in Uzbekistan do not have experience in designing and operating dedicated financial products for EE and RE equipment and materials 1.9 Standard homes with EE and low-carbon designs are not currently available in Uzbekistan 1.10 EE and low-carbon houses are not currently available under the RHP program in Uzbekistan 1.11 A rural TNA has not previously been conducted 1.12 Companies offering EE materials/ technologies and RE technologies do not currently have a sales chain for rural single-family houses 1.13 One building code for rural house with requirements for energy performance has been adopted 1.14 Compliance with applicable energy performance standards has not been formally documented for the residential sector as a whole 1.15 Gosarchitectstroy does not currently appraise rural housing designs with a view to a “low-carbon” designation or other 1.16 Currently, land-use plans and regulations do not take into account climate considerations or energy-savings 1.17 Currently, standard practice does not

Results as of December 2020. 1.7 528 low-carbon mortgages in 5 regions issued through green mortgage scheme operated by the local mortgage bank (Qishloq Qurilish Bank). National Bank of Uzbekistan (NBU) and Ipoteka Bank (IB) planned to be a subject for HACT informed that they prioritize small-medium businesses to support creation of new jobs in the upcoming years but mortgages, and HACTs therefore were not conducted.
1.8 528 (2,200 people of the borrowers’ families) rural low-income households in 5 regions accessed the green mortgage product for low-carbon affordable housing operated by the local mortgage bank (Qishloq Qurilish Bank). The proportion of participation by women as green mortgage borrowers is 67% that is greater than the proportion of participation by women in the standard (energy efficient) mortgages (30%) of the Rural Housing Programme.
1.9 528 (2,200 people) households (67% of women-led households) have access to new low-carbon rural houses equipped with rooftop PVs (600 W) to cover electricity needs for for lighting and home appliances (refrigerator, TV and mobile phone charger).
1.10 60 rural houses (representing the standard inefficient, energy efficient and low-carbon houses) are under energy auditing by the contracted national company. Conduction energy audits of rural housing has been delayed by Covid-19 pandemic related travel restrictions to regions in Uzbekistan. The results achieved as of today show that the specific consumption of standard inefficient family house is 3 times higher than the energy efficient one (426 kWh/m2 vs134.8 kWh/m2).
1.11 TNA focused on rural technologies needs related to housing conducted among rural households (with particular focus on rural women respondents (52 in Fergana region, 54 in Kashkadarya region, and 50 in Karakalpakstan). Results and corresponding recommendations are summarized in TNA publication produced in Uzbek, Russian and English in late November 2020, and will be widely disseminated among the relevant government agencies and other stakeholders from January 2021.
1.12 In total 4 solar panel manufacturers benefited from increased volume production volume in 2019-2020 LLC “All-Solar” and LLC “Solar Nature” solar manufacturers increased their production volume by 20-30% in 2019 and 2020 in comparison with 2018. (Source: LLC “All-Solar” and LLC “Solar Nature”)
Moreover, 85 companies benefited in 2019, including 80 construction companies, 1 basalt insulation board manufacturer, 2 polystyrene foam board manufacturers, 1 double glazed insulated window manufacturer, 1 insulated metal framed doors manufacturer; and 32 companies benefited in 2020, including 22 construction companies, 5 basalt insulation board manufacturers, 3 polystyrene foam board manufacturers, 1 double glazed insulated window manufacturer, 1 insulated metal framed doors manufacturer) through supply chain for energy efficient rural housing in 2019-2020. (Source: Minstroy) Since construction materials companies’ production capacities could not meet demand for thermal insulation, in 2020, 4 new companies (LLC “Bazalt Wool”, JV LLC “Petrawool”, “Angren Insulation” and “Akfa Insulation”) were established and started production of basalt insulation boards. All 1,328 (800 in 2019 and 528 in 2020) housing units were installed with double glazed insulated windows, insulated metal-framed doors, basalt insulation boards, polystyrene foam boards and with solar panels (300Watt capacity in 2019 and 600Watt capacity in 2020).
1.13 New building code (as none of approved standards related to PVs exist) and manual on “photovoltaic station” (PVs) developed and approved by the Government and allows streamlined work in the design of energy-efficient and low-carbon facilities.
1.16 2 spatial planning regulations analyzed, and recommendations on improving corresponding second legislation to eliminate the existing gaps related to energy efficiency and climate considerations formulated bidding documents related to selection of design and research institution developed. Bidding process postponed to 2021 due to Covid-19 pandemic related restrictions.
1.18 More than 90% of 528 households are aware of the benefits of EE and LC houses constructed in 2020, which is determined through the independent Assurance Report done (October 2020).
1.19 Two PR companies contracted based on the long-term agreement with UNDP to implement the project communication strategy. In 2020, the contracted PR companies conducted 20 visits to 9 regions (Khorezm, Samarkand, Bukhara, Namangan, Surkhandarya, Kashkadarya, Tashkent, Ferghana regions and Republic of Karakalpakstan) and widely covered the project activities such as trainings on the use of energy efficient and low-carbon materials and technologies in the construction of housing conducted in 5 regions (Bukhara, Namangan, Tashkent regions and Republic of Karakalpakstan) with participation of 100 local specialists (3 females); energy audits conducted 5 pilot regions (including Khorezm, Samarkand, Bukhara, Surkhandarya and Ferghana regions in both local and national mass media. Wide public awareness campaign conducted by the Project through local TV channels, newspapers, social networks including Facebook and Twitter, and several popular news websites. In total, over 72 mentions, including number of press-releases and articles about the project related activities in local media, including television, radio, newspapers, magazines, official websites of the Ministry of Construction and UNDP, as well as social networks like Facebook and Twitter.
1.20 IT needs assessment of Ministry of Construction conducted, based on which several IT equipment including server procured. IT Company contracted and development of software is underway. Delivering of final output of IT software to Ministry of Construction postponed to the 2021 due to Covid-19 pandemic restrictions delaying IT equipment transfer including the server for integration of developed software.
1.21 Project staff, Ministry of construction and major stakeholders are aware of this analysis and action plan through regularly shared monitoring reports:5 monitoring reports on 5 pilot regions; as well Assurance Reports prepared by an Independent Assessor on the contracted Green mortgages, which underlines that of the total 528 green mortgages 353 are issued to female borrowers (representing 67%) in 2020.

Target 1 1.7 National arrangements of channelling international climate financing (GEF funds) to launch Green Mortgage Scheme implemented and institutionalized, and HACT for selected financial institution conducted 1.9 At least 9 standard designs for EE and LC homes are available in Uzbekistan 1.11 At least one focus group of women is convened during the rural TNA stakeholder consultations conducted 1.12 Database on companies in each of the five pilot areas in Uzbekistan having multiple sales (volume) related to rural housing construction updated 1.13 At least 3 strengthened building codes with stricter thermal performance requirements (by at least 30%) are fully elaborated 1.14 Rates of compliance with applicable energy performance standards in residential building codes in rural housing constructed in 2017 analysed 1.15 140 specialists (architects, builders, designers, etc.) trained in the new EE codes and designs 1.16 Existing land-use plans and regulations analyzed and selected for introducing energy savings and/or climate considerations 1.17 Existing mechanism of decision-making in rural communities/local administrations constructed in 2017 analyzed to incorporate climate change (gender mainstreamed) considerations into decision-making process 1.18 Awareness of project stakeholders, homeowners and rural housing mortgage borrowers (gender disaggregated) about EE and low-carbon housing and infrastructure assessed, and baseline established 1.19 Project communication strategy, which activities explicitly consider gender developed 1.20 Monitoring and Evaluation systems are operational 1.21 Project staff and stakeholders are aware of gender issues in project monitoring through shared project and CO monitoring reports

Target 1. Results as of December 2018. 1.7 Performance Based Payment (PBP) modality and payment schedule for $ 1M grant funding to cover incremental part of mortgages for approximately 524 energy efficient (95%) and low-carbon (5%) affordable rural housing units (family houses and apartments in multi-story buildings) agreed with the national Qishloq Qurilish Bank (QQB). HACT for QQB conducted. Low-risk assessment makes QQB eligible for PBP modality. 1.9 21 standard designs for EE and LC rural houses developed by the national design company Qishloq Qurilish Loyiha (QQL) with support/inputs provided by the project national and international experts. They are nationally adopted and are available in Uzbekistan. 1.11 TNA report format identified. Rural TNA research and focus group meetings are postponed for 2019. 1.12 45 companies manufacturing EE construction materials with sales in the domestic market identified and informed a database of companies available in Uzbekistan, based on which a nationwide catalogue of EE construction materials manufacturers by region and by product is done and to be publicly accessed. 1.13 3 strengthened building codes with stricter thermal performance requirements (by at least 30%) developed and nationally adopted. They will come into force and become mandatory on 02 January 2019. 1.14 The rural houses constructed in 2017 comply with mandatory building codes. No mandatory energy performance standards in 2017. Energy performance standards will be introduced from 02 January 2019 under the three building codes re-worked by the project. 1.15 220 (10% female) specialists (architects, builders, designers, engineers, regional authority) trained in the new house designs, building codes and certification in Tashkent City and five regions - Samarkand, Bukhara, Surkhandarya, Khorezm and Ferghana in Nov-Dec 2018. 1.16 6 regulations and 5 land use plans analysed. No energy savings and climate change considerations are taken into account in the development of land use plans. 1.17 300 respondents (43% female) surveyed in 6 regions and existing mechanism of decision-making in rural communities/local administrations in affordable houses constructed in 2017 analysed. No direct climate change considerations in decision making identified. Nevertheless, 62% stated that construction of EE houses reduced air pollution and GHG emissions to incorporate climate change (gender mainstreamed) considerations into decision-making process. 1.18 100% (six out of six national banks) are aware of green mortgage scheme for EE and low-carbon housing through participation in targeted trainings conducted by the project. Representative of two banks are familiar with best practices of green mortgage tools and EE housing through participation in a study tour to USA in September 2018. 56% of project beneficiaries from government agencies (Ministry of Construction, Ministry of Finance, Ministry of Economy, Ministry of Foreign Affairs, State Committee of Ecology and Environment Protection, and Uzbekenergo) are aware of EE and low-carbon housing through participation in project events, including trainings, round tables, and a study tour to USA. 300 (43% feamales) households surveyed in six regions and informed about EE and low-carbon housing, which is 11.5% of potential amount of people who will get an access to EE/LC housing to be pilot by project in 2019 through issuing green mortgages. EE awareness baseline established as 52% of respondents states EE house is comfortable and cost-saving (economical) house. Level of awareness about EE and low-carbon housing among project beneficiaries is 73% for men and 27% for women. 1.19 Yes, project communication strategy with activities that explicitly consider gender mainstreaming and gender sensitivity developed. 1.20 Monitoring and evaluation system is operational through reporting in Atlas, PIR, and ROAR, and UNDAF reporting for 2018 as well as monitoring report done by the Country Office. 1.21 Project staff and stakeholders are aware of gender issues in project monitoring through shared project and CO monitoring reports (PIR, Quality Assurance, gender trainings passed by project staff).

Target 1 1.7 At least one mechanism to finance EE and RE technologies in rural houses is operational in Uzbekistan 1.8 At least 265 (1,325 people) households accessed the dedicated financial products on low-carbon housing that designed and operated by financial institutions. The proportion of participation by women as green mortgage borrowers should be equal to or greater than the proportion of participation by women in the standard mortgages of the Rural Housing Programme 1.9 At least 265 (1,325 people) households (20% of women-led households) have access to new rural houses featuring advanced EE/RE technologies 1.11 Rural technology needs assessment (TNA) conducted and reflects current needs of both men and women 1.13 At least 3 strengthened codes with stricter thermal performance requirements (by at least 30%) are fully elaborated and submitted for approval by the Government 1.16 Existing land-use plans and regulations analyzed and selected for introducing energy savings and/or climate considerations 1.17 Existing mechanism of decision-making in rural communities/local administrations analyzed. Community-based mechanism of decision making to incorporate climate change considerations (gender mainstreamed) into decision-making process is articulated 1.18 At least 90% of project participants (households) are aware of the benefits of EE and LC houses constructed in 2019 1.19 Project communication strategy is tested on women's and men's communication channels in rural areas in 2 pilot regions. 1.21 Project staff and stakeholders are aware of gender issues in project monitoring through shared project and CO monitoring reports

Target 1. Results as of December 2019. 1.7 Green mortgage scheme is operated by the local mortgage bank (Qishloq Qurilish Bank), which issued 800 low-carbon mortgages in 5 regions, in which incremental part of low-carbon solutions (PVs and SWH for lighting and hot water needs) amounted to USD1 mln was covered from GEF grant funding through piloting Performance Based Payment (PBP) tool by UNDP to boost demand and private investments into green buildings.
1.8 800 (4,000 people of the borrows families) rural low-income households in 5 regions accessed the green mortgage product for low-carbon affordable housing designed and operated by the local mortgage bank (Qishloq Qurilish Bank). The proportion of participation by women as green mortgage borrowers is 53% that is greater than the proportion of participation by women in the standard (energy efficient) mortgages (30%) of the Rural Housing Programme.
1.9 800 (4000 people) households (53% of women-led households) have access to new low-carbon rural houses equipped with rooftop PVs for lighting needs, of which 10 households are equipped with solar water heaters to cover their seasonal needs (during out off heating period) in hot water.
1.11 TNA conducted among rural women of Fergana (52 women), Kashkadarya (54 women) regions and the Republic of Karakalpakstan (50 women). In total 156 rural women from various social categories (school and kindergarten teachers, farmers, nurses, entrepreneurs, housewives) were convened. Based on the assessment results, technological needs is analyzed to identify barriers/ constraints that impede utilization of energy efficient and low-carbon technologies by women in rural areas is identified and recommendations on how to overcome them to improve their living conditions is formulated.
1.13 2 building codes on roofing and flooring approved by the Ministry of construction in October 2019. Thermal performance of up to 30% is achieved. Further, manuals are developed for 3 building codes: 1. On constructive thermal engineering; 2. Installation of solar water heaters; 3. Norms of energy costs for heating, ventilation and air-conditioning of public buildings.
1.16 6 regulations were analyzed by the Project and 2 of them selected to be reworked in 2020.
1.17 Reviewed the existing regulations on decision-making process on siting, settlement infrastructure, land allocation, permits for construction, use of building materials, energy consumption, environmental protection and climate change, and identify the corresponding decisions that could be made at Mahallas and local administration level (gender sensitive and gender disaggregated). Formulated specific recommendations (directed at the various relevant parties) on incorporating climate change, housing and infrastructure energy efficiency into the decision-making process at community level in rural settlements and conducted series of trainings in 5 pilot regions.
1.18 More than 90% of 800 households are aware of benefits of EE and LC rural houses through Qishloq Qurilish Bank loan departments. Project staff visits to households with all major stakeholders (including Qishloq Qurilish Invest and Qishloq Qurilish Loyiha). All 800 households were provided instructions on use of PVS and SWH in Uzbek and Russian, developed by the Project. Promotional video has been developed on the benefits of Green mortgage. Infographics were developed on benefits of EE and LC houses, as well as green mortgage as a tool to purchase EE and LC houses.
1.19 Development of communication strategy led to the recruitment of PR company. During 4th quarter of 2019, the recruited PR company has conducted 12 visits to 9 regions (including 5 pilot regions of Samarkand, Bukhara, Khorezm, Surkhandarya and Ferghana) and widely covered Project activities in both local and national mass media. In particular, the PR company widely covered trainings conducted in 5 pilot regions, whereby more than 500 local specialists were trained, including over 100 female specialists. Also, wide public awareness campaign conducted by the Project through local TV channels, newspapers, social networks including Facebook and Twitter, and several popular news websites. In total, over 46 press-releases and articles published on Project related activities in local media, including television, radio, newspapers, magazines, official websites of the Ministry of Construction and UNDP, as well as social networks like Facebook and Twitter.
1.21 Comprehensive Gender analysis and Action plan within the framework of Rural Housing project developed. Project staff, Ministry of construction and major stakeholders are made aware of this analysis and action plan through constant monitoring reports. Project shared five monitoring reports on 5 pilot regions with the main stakeholder Ministry of Construction in October 2019. Project also shared Assurance Reports prepared by an Independent Assessor on the contracted Green mortgages, which underlines that of the total 800 green mortgages 424 are issued to female borrowers (representing 53%) in 2019.

Targets for 2021. 1.1 At least 5,275 t CO2eq of direct GHG emissions reduced or avoided from the EE and RE measures implemented in the green mortgage houses; and 11,236 t CO2eq GHG emissions reduced or avoided from the introduction of stricter building codes. Total direct GHG emissions avoided: 16,511 tCO2eq over an assumed technology and materials lifetime of 20 years. 1.2 At least 128,893 GJ energy savings achieved through direct investment, code strengthening, and other measures. 1.3 Investments of at least USD19 million are leveraged (not including GEF financing). 1.4 At least 390 households (appr. 1,950 people. of which appr. 975 are female) use low-GHG systems in the form of solar PV units and/or efficient technologies. 1.5 At least one new development partnership for improved EE and/or sustainable energy solutions targeting underserved communities/ groups and women. 1.6 Rating of satisfaction with indoor air temperature compliance with recommended norms is at least comparable with houses in the selected control group. 1.7 At least one mechanism to finance EE and RE technologies in rural houses is operational in Uzbekistan. 1.8 At least 798 (3,990 people) households accessed the dedicated financial products on low-carbon housing that designed and operated by financial institutions. The proportion of participation by women as green mortgage borrowers should be equal to or greater than the proportion of participation by women in the standard mortgages of the RHP. 1.9 At least 798 (3,990 people) households (35% of women-led households) have access to new rural houses featuring advanced EE/RE technologies. 1.10 At least 60 energy audits of rural houses constructed in 2020 conducted to demonstrate that the EE/LC houses complied with indoor climate regulations with lower energy expenditures compared to a control group of standard RHP houses. 1.11 Rural technology needs assessment (TNA) conducted and reflects current needs of both men and women. 1.12 At least 1-2 companies in each of the five pilot areas in Uzbekistan have multiple sales (volume) related to rural housing construction. 1.13 At least 3 strengthened building codes with stricter energy consumption and thermal performance requirements (by at least 30%) related to residential housing adopted by the Government By the project mid-term, building codes on energy consumption and thermal performance with revisions requiring 30 percent lower energy consumption for residential buildings will be fully elaborated and submitted for approval by the Government. 1.14 All new houses constructed under the RHP in 2020 conform to applicable energy standards in building codes. 1.15 500 specialists (architects, builders, designers, etc.) certified/ successfully completing training in the new codes, design review, certification, and compliance issues and techniques, including 40 percent women. 1.16 At least one siting regulation and one village-level land use plan that promote energy savings and/or climate considerations developed. 1.17 At least 5 communities in project pilot areas have tested a community-based mechanism of decision-making to incorporate climate change considerations into decision-making, including 30 percent women participants. 1.18 a) At least 90% of project participants (participating households, participating banks, and relevant government agencies involved in project implementation) are aware of the benefits of EE and LC houses constructed in 2019-2020. b) At least 5% of all rural homeowners (including owners of new RHP houses, existing RHP houses, and other privately-owned single-family houses) in pilot areas are aware of the benefits of EE and LC houses. c) Awareness among project beneficiaries does not differ significantly between women and men in target groups surveyed." 1.19 Communication strategies reflected women’s and men’s communication channels in rural areas on an ongoing basis implemented in remaining 3 pilot regions. 1.20 Mid-term evaluation (MTE) findings extracted. 1.21 Project staff and stakeholders are aware of gender issues in project monitoring through shared project and CO monitoring reports.
